precedents.citation: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd. 1 1940 A.C. 1014

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, Mr. Gopalakrishnan, learned counsel for the respondents, relied on some remarks of the House of Lords in Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd. 1 , where it was held Counsel for the appellant argued that a contractual right to personal service was a personal right of the employer and was incapable of being transferred by him to anyone else, and that a duty to serve a specific master could not be part of the property

precedents.case_name: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: contractual right to personal service is a personal right of the employer and cannot be transferred without the employee's consent; the old contract must be terminated and a new one entered into
precedents.cited_holding: the benefit of a contract entered into by A to render personal service to X cannot be transferred by X to Y without A's consent, which is the same thing as saying that, in order to produce the desired result, the old contract between A and X would have to be terminated by notice or by mutual consent and a new contract of service entered into by agreement between A and Y.
